summary: Feature request to enhance TypeScript's SignalDefinition and QueryDefinition to retain type information about signal/query names, enabling type-safe enforcement of legal signals/queries at compile time.
userImpact: Developers cannot currently use TypeScript's type system to enforce which signals and queries are legal to send to a workflow, limiting the ability to create type-safe signal/query systems.
rootCause: SignalDefinition and QueryDefinition do not preserve the literal type of the name string, only the string type itself, preventing type-level differentiation between different signals.
proposedFix: Make the name parameter a generic type parameter in SignalDefinition/QueryDefinition (e.g., Name extends string), allowing the specific signal name to be captured in the type system. Three implementation options discussed: type parameter duplication, curried functions, or opt-in type specificity.
keyQuote: SignalDefinition does not retain the type of its name, making it difficult to create systems that enforce legal signals in the type system
